physDesc.p: The letter consists of 2 sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides of each. On the top of the first page is “Aldington” written in pencil. On the top right of each page is the date, and on the top left of each one (excluding the first) is R.A. and a page number.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p: I sent you and Hilda each two copies of “Some Imagist Poets 1916” by mail yesterday. I hope that you will like them. I know just how you will feel about the tribute to Harriet, and I feel so too. But we have gone over all that before, and there is no use weeping over spilt milk.

What I feel even worse about is that I forgot to put in Flint’s dedication to you in front of his poem “Easter”. He sent it as an after-thought on a postal card, and, somehow, the postal card got mislaid and I never found it until yesterday. I have written to him telling him how sorry I was for this stupidity on my part, and saying that I would correct it if the book went into a second edition. But I hardly hope for this luck this year, for the reasons that I have already told you.

I enclose the only review we have, which came out on the day of publication last Saturday – nominal publication, that is, for, as a matter of fact, the books were not on the market until Monday, which is the reason I could not ship any copies to you until yesterday. I think it is, on the whole, a very good review, and I think it a very good idea to have put in your woodcuts. I did it on purpose, because, as you see from the enclosed advertisement, the publishers undertook to feature Fletcher and me in this first announcement. That was quite a national and commercial venture on their part, for our poems are well-known here and these particular poems of ours have been much discussed in the papers. But it seemed to me that the English side was being rather badly represented. I suppose it is natural that American reviewers should pay more attention to American contributors, as the English reviewers do the English contributors. But these woodcuts of you and Flint seemed to make the balance square – square from the advertising view, that is. I am afraid it is impossible to make the American reviewers speak as much about the English side of our book as about the American. But that is more than evened up, because the American reviewers do speak constantly of the English side, whereas the English reviewers pay almost no attention to the American side.

The advance sales have been about normal. I saw Greenslet yesterday, and he thought about 250 copies had been ordered before publication. He had not heard from Constable yet, but he thought they would take about 100 copies. You say you know somebody at Constable’s, and as they are printing Hilda’s book in the Autumn, perhaps you could get your friend to take a real interest and push this a bit. Ferris tells me that they are particularly interested in Aiken’s book; which is amusing, as Aiken’s book is doing nothing on this side of the ocean. I am sending you a copy, so that you may see what it is like. Aiken is one of our bitterest enemies, and personally I think his book an insincere copy of “Spoon River”, although I admit that it is clever. But it is such a false picture of life on the vaudeville stage that it does not take at all over here.

I am reviewing yours and Flint’s books for Braithwaite’s new “Poetry Review”. He has a backer who is quite well off, and although they are paying very little at present, they have a distinct commercial sense. The man is a lawyer and knows the world, and Braithwaite has been in journalism too long not to know the ropes of that business. If it falls down it will be because of his incurable enthusiasm for everything, and his lack of judgment. But he is the only person here who has been steadily and consistently loyal to us, as I have written to you several times. The paper is got up entirely without any bias. He intends to print all schools and have all poetry review represented in his criticism. This will, of course, frequently irritate us, but on the other hand he is most welcoming to our work and will print us with great frequency, I think. They printed 4,000 copies of the first number, and it is the only one of the poetry magazines which has been taken hold of by the American News Company. This company owns all the railroad and subway news stands throughout the entire country, and it is a great help to be constantly on sale in that way. I have subscribed to the paper to be sent you regularly, and although I think it may often annoy you to tears, I am sure in the end it will be a good thing for us to have it succeed.

Braithwaite’s “Anthology” is already in its fifth thousand, and all these things help us all. The more people read poetry, the sooner we shall have discerning people reading it. I have just contracted to give a series of four lectures in Chicago next Winter on “Contemporary Poetry”; and, of course, one of the lectures will be devoted to our group. I think I shall repeat these lectures in Boston and possibly in New York. Mr. Marsh, of the Macmillan Company, tells me that he can trace increasing sales in the towns in which I have been speaking.

I think this volume is a great advance on the last, but I should not wonder if Braithwaite were right when he says that reviewers will find it more difficult of comprehension. I will send you the reviews, as I did last year.
I have not heard from you for ages, it seems to me, and I cannot tell you how much I miss it when I do not get any letters from you or Hilda.
Flint has never acknowledged the letter containing the money order for royalties, which I sent him in February, and I have written to ask him if he ever received it. Do find out and let me know.
